Award.AwardTitle: Simulation Studies of Plasmaspheric Plume Density Structure/Ion Composition and Plume Plasma Transport to Dayside Magnetopause and Polar Cap
Award.AbstractNarration:
A plasmaspheric plume is a region of dense cold ionospheric plasma extending outward into the magnetosphere from the nominal location of the plasmapause. It has a limited width in azimuth. This study will use and improve the dynamic-fluid-kinetic-plasmasphere-ionosphere (DyFKPI) model. This model combines self-consistently a fluid based model of the ionosphere with a particle based model of the plasmasphere. It will be used to determine the density distributions of electrons and ions (H+, He+, and O+) along plume magnetic field lines and provide formulas that can be used to determine the density along the flux tube. The second part of this study will quantify the plasmaspheric plasma mass delivered to the dayside magnetospause as a function of magnetospheric activity. This research will investigate how plasmaspheric plumes deliver plasma to the polar cap and contribute to magnetospheric plasma circulation. IMAGE RPI data will be used in this study and compared with simulation derived density distributions.

While the research is rather narrowly focused on the structure and impact of the plasma plumes the resulting formulas will be valuable in other studies of magnetospheric physics. The grant will support a graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The plasmasphere is a toroidal shaped region in the inner magnetosphere dominated by cold and dense plasma (compared to the plasma in the outer magnetosphere) originating from the ionosphere. It is a component of the coupled solar wind-magnetosphere-ionosphere system. The plasmasphere is bounded by a transition region with sharp density drop, which is called the plasmapause. The shape and location of the plasmapause, as well as overall structures of the plasmasphere, are determined by the competitive sunward plasma flow and the plasma corotation with the Earth, together with the upward flow of the ionospheric plasma along the geomagnetic field lines. While the corotation basically does not change with time, the sunward flow of the plasma is strongly influenced by the solar wind (the plasma emanated from the Sun) and the interplanetary magnetic field imbedded in the solar wind, which both can change dramatically. The ionospheric plasma upflow also may be affected by the solar wind/interplanetary magnetic field conditions and is particularly controlled by the solar radiation. All these changing factors make the plasmasphere a dynamic space region around the Earth. A prominent feature during the magnetic active periods is that a plume-like high density region is emanated from the plasmasphere toward the magnetopause, which is the outer boundary of the magnetosphere. This plasmasphere plume with the high density plasma from the plasmasphere, particularly the heavier mass oxygen ions, may significantly decrease the solar wind-magnetosphere coupling rate, more precisely the magnetic reconnection rate. The magnetic reconnection is a process that the oppositely directed magnetic field lines in highly conducting plasma break and reconnect, releasing magnetic energy to thermal and kinetic energies. The magnetic reconnection is believed to be the major process that the solar wind/interplanetary magnetic field transfer the energy and momentum to the Earth’s magnetosphere and thus affects the Earth’s space weather.

 The primary goal of this project is to quantitatively determine the density and density ratios of different ion species (hydrogen H+/ helium He+/oxygen O+ ions) and effects of the plasmasphere plasma transported to the magnetopause through the plasmasphere plume on the magnetic reconnection. To meet the goals of the project, we have completed the development of a Dynamic Fluid-Kinetic Plasmasphere-Ionosphere (DyFK) simulation model. The model solves self-consistently densities, velocities and temperatures parallel and perpendicular to the magnetic field of the multiple ion (H+/He+/O+) species along a magnetic field line from 120 km in the northern hemisphere to 120 km in the southern hemisphere. The multiple ion species (H+/He+/O+) are for the first time treated as particles in the kinetic simulation model above the topside ionosphere along field lines. The simulations provide density, velocity and temperature distributions of H+/He+/O+ ions along the geomagnetic field lines within the plasmaspheric plume, allowing us to obtain information of the plasmaspheric plumes along the entire field line not just in the equatorial plane or at the ionospheric height. The major finding from the DyFK simulations is that the plasmaspheric plume can provide an equatorial plasma density to the magnetopause up to three orders of magnitude higher than the typical magnetospheric density. The higher density can be further enhanced by the wave-particle interaction. As a consequence of such mass load through the plasmaspheric plume, the reconnection rate at the dayside magnetopause may be substantially reduced in association with the plumes. The simulation produce phase-space and pitch angle distributions of multiple ion species, as well as density, velocity, and anisotropic temperature distributions along the flux tubes within the plasmaspheric plume, which are critical information to studies on generation and propagation of various waves, which may interact with radiation belt electrons and ions. Therefore the results from the DyFK simulations will have impacts on our understanding of radiation belt dynamics.

In addition we have also developed a simulation model to investigate dynamic magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling. The simulation using this model reveals the propagation of the electric currents flowing along the geomagnetic field lines (i.e., Birkland currents) at aurora latitudes and the dynamic formation of the closure electric currents flowing perpendicular to the magnetic field lines. The latter is called the Pedersen currents when it propagates with the front of the Birkland currents to the E-layer of the ionosphere at about 100-120 km altitudes. This study provided a physically more faithful description of the dynamics of the Birkland currents and their closure currents in the ionosphere and will have important impact on the study of other magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling phenomena that involve the electric current system connecting the magnetosphere and ionosphere.
